summary: An educational video by Dr. William J. Doria discussing the principles of spectroscopy, including absorption and emission spectroscopy, the interaction of light with matter, and the equipment used in spectroscopic techniques.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a title screen displaying the text "Physical Chemistry II Video Lecture 31 Dr. William J. Doria" against a gradient background transitioning from black to gray. The text is presented in three different colors: green, blue, and red, respectively. The scene then transitions to a classroom setting where a group of students is seated at desks, attentively taking notes. The students are dressed casually, with one wearing a blue shirt and a long necklace, another in a plaid shirt, and a third in a white shirt with a black wristwatch. The atmosphere is focused and studious. Following this, the video shifts to a slide with the word "spectroscopy" in pink text on a gray background. The slide then expands to include a definition in blue text: "the study of the interactions that occur between matter and light, and the practical applications of those interactions." The video maintains a consistent educational theme, emphasizing the subject matter of spectroscopy and its significance in physical chemistry.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with upbeat, bright music that sounds like it could be from a stock music library. Following this musical interlude, a man begins to speak in a conversational and informative tone, introducing a series of videos and alluding to an examination. He shifts the topic to spectroscopy, describing it as "the study of how light and matter interact." The music fades back in softly to end the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide introducing the concept of spectroscopy, defined as the study of interactions between matter and light, and their practical applications. The word "spectroscopy" is prominently displayed in pink at the top, with the definition in blue below. The background is a plain gray. As the video progresses, additional text appears, explaining that an absorbed photon is transformed into kinetic and potential energy in a molecule. The slide then transitions to a diagram illustrating energy levels, with a yellow dot representing an electron at a specific energy level. The diagram includes a vertical axis labeled "energy" and a horizontal axis labeled "n," with various energy levels marked. The video concludes with the addition of molecular structures on the right side of the diagram, depicting atoms in different colors (white, red, blue, and gray) connected by bonds, representing different molecules. The background remains consistently gray throughout the video, maintaining a simple and educational atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing spectroscopy and how light and matter interact, describing the transformation of energy and potential outcomes such as electrons moving to higher energy levels or molecules vibrating. He speaks in an informative, slightly academic tone, and transitions to mentioning the difficulty of visualizing energy transformation.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a graphical representation of an energy level diagram on the left side, featuring a yellow dot positioned at the energy level labeled '1/9'. On the right side, two molecular structures are displayed, each composed of atoms represented by spheres in different colors: red, blue, gray, and white. The background is a muted gray, and the molecular structures are set against a darker gray backdrop. The scene then transitions to a three-dimensional, brown, irregularly shaped object floating against a plain gray background. This object appears to be rotating slowly, showcasing its smooth, rounded surface. Subsequently, a red sinusoidal wave is introduced beneath the brown object, with an arrow at the end pointing to the right, suggesting a wave-like motion or energy transfer. The video concludes with the brown object continuing to rotate above the red wave, maintaining the same gray background throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the challenges of picturing photons, suggesting that "thinking of a photon as a particle" is a poor model. He continues, stating it is better to think of photons as waves, while cautioning that even that can be misleading. The speaker uses a calm, instructional tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a simple illustration featuring a brown, irregularly shaped object floating above a red wavy line with an arrow pointing to the right, set against a plain gray background. This setup suggests a concept related to waves or oscillations. As the video progresses, a second red wavy line appears below the first, with dashed lines connecting the two, indicating a relationship or interaction between the two waves. The scene then transitions to a complex black and white diagram on the right side of the frame, depicting a network of interconnected nodes labeled with letters and numbers, such as O1, O2, C1, C2, C3, H1, H2, and H3. The diagram is surrounded by intricate, curved lines that resemble wave patterns, suggesting a scientific or mathematical representation of a system or process. The left side of the frame remains blank, emphasizing the diagram on the right. The video concludes with this detailed diagram, highlighting the complexity and interconnectedness of the system being illustrated.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker, calmly explaining that a light wave is an electromagnetic wave. He elaborates that this wave is made of oscillating electric and magnetic fields, which he attempts to clarify by saying, "a picture like this would be a bit more realistic." He then transitions to discussing the electric and magnetic fields of a molecule, saying it is thanks to "the electrons and protons in the molecule."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a black and white diagram with a complex network of lines and nodes, labeled with letters and numbers such as O1, O2, C1, C2, C3, H1, H2, H3, and H5. The diagram is intricate, with lines curving and intersecting to form a web-like structure. A red wave-like line appears on the left side of the frame, moving towards the diagram and eventually entering the network, suggesting an interaction or influence on the system. The background remains plain and white, emphasizing the diagram and the red line. The video maintains a static focus on the diagram and the red line's movement, with no additional elements or changes in the environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker in an instructional tone explaining interactions between photons and molecules, specifically the electric fields, and mentioning future discussion about magnetic interactions in NMR spectroscopy.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white diagram featuring a network of interconnected nodes labeled O1, O2, C1, C2, C3, H1, H2, and H3, surrounded by intricate, flowing lines that create a sense of movement and complexity. The scene then transitions to a series of scientific graphs and charts. The first graph displays absorption spectra with peaks labeled at 390nm, 610nm, 765nm, and 855nm, indicating different wavelengths of light absorbed by a substance. The second graph shows a series of sharp peaks representing vibrational frequencies, with the x-axis labeled in wavenumbers (cm^-1) and the y-axis labeled as intensity. The third graph presents a broad spectrum with multiple peaks and troughs, likely representing a different type of spectroscopic data. The video maintains a focus on these scientific visuals, emphasizing the detailed analysis of molecular or material properties through spectroscopy.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by discussing spectroscopy, mentioning UV-Vis, IR, and rotational types, and emphasizing the role of electrical interactions. He says that in most cases "photons are interacting with the electrons rather than the nuclei". He concludes by noting the importance of angular momentum and states "here's an important thing to remember".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a gray background displaying the text "an electron has two forms of angular momentum:" in blue font. It then lists the two forms: "1. orbital angular momentum (l)" in blue and "2. spin angular momentum (s)" in orange. The scene transitions to a black and white diagram of a molecular structure with various labeled atoms and lines representing bonds, set against a gray background. Following this, a graph with horizontal lines labeled with numbers and a vertical axis labeled "energy" appears, with a yellow dot at the bottom. The video then poses the question "How do we study the absorption and emission of photons by molecules?" in blue and orange text. The final frames illustrate absorption spectroscopy, showing a light bulb labeled "Polychromatic Light Source" with an arrow pointing towards a yellow rectangle labeled "Sample," all set against a gray background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker who discusses how electrons and photons have momentum and spin, and how a photon can transfer momentum to a molecule. He explains the interactions between photons and molecules, particularly the absorption of photons and the use of a polychromatic light source, speaking in an educational and descriptive tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a gray background displaying the word "Monochromator" in orange text, followed by a definition in blue text explaining that a monochromator is a device that isolates a small range of wavelengths from polychromatic light. Below the definition, the words "Prism" and "Diffraction Grating" appear in pink text. The scene transitions to a 3D model of a prism, with the word "Prism" in pink text above it, and then to a prism refracting white light into a spectrum of colors on a black background. Next, the video shows a 3D model of a diffraction grating with the word "Diffraction Grating" in pink text above it, followed by a close-up of a CD being held by two hands, demonstrating its ability to diffract light into a spectrum of colors. The video concludes with a close-up of the CD, highlighting the spectrum of colors it produces when light is shone on it.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker with a didactic tone introduces a monochromator as a device that separates polychromatic light into its component wavelengths. He explains the two most common types, prisms and diffraction gratings, and describes how prisms work to refract incoming light. Then, he pivots to describe diffraction gratings, explaining their reflective material and series of closely spaced parallel ridges. He uses the analogy of light reflecting off of a CD or DVD to illustrate the rainbow effect. Finally, he reiterates that light in a spectrometer is separated into its component wavelengths after passing through the monochromator.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a diagram illustrating the concept of absorption spectroscopy. It features a light bulb labeled "Polychromatic Light Source" on the left, emitting a beam of light that passes through a prism labeled "Monochromator," which separates the light into its constituent colors. The separated light then travels towards a yellow rectangle labeled "Sample," representing the material being analyzed. The background is a plain gray color, and the text "Absorption spectroscopy" is prominently displayed at the top in pink. As the video progresses, a slit is introduced between the monochromator and the sample, allowing only a specific wavelength of light to pass through. This is followed by the addition of a detector on the right side of the sample, symbolized by a starburst pattern, indicating the measurement of the light that has passed through the sample. The diagram remains static throughout, with no people or environmental details, focusing solely on the scientific process of absorption spectroscopy. The text and labels are consistent, providing clear educational content on the subject matter.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker explaining a process. He says that they can "select a wavelength of our choice" by placing a card with a slit in the light's path to allow certain wavelengths to reach the sample while blocking others. He details how the light then passes through the sample to a detector, which reports the intensity of the light, and that they can select different wavelengths by adjusting a knob on the spectrometer. By repeating the adjustments for many wavelengths, they can generate a spectrum. The speaker uses a calm and informative tone throughout the explanation.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a graph displaying multiple curves, each representing different temperatures ranging from 298.15 K to 338.15 K, plotted against wavelength in nanometers. The curves illustrate the distribution of light intensity across various wavelengths at different temperatures. The scene then transitions to an image of a glowing light bulb with a green arrow pointing towards a rectangular object, indicating the direction of light emission. However, a red prohibition sign appears over the rectangular object, suggesting that the light is not allowed to pass through it. The video then shifts to a color wheel, showcasing a spectrum of colors arranged in a circular pattern, with numbers ranging from 1 to 36 marking different color segments. The color wheel is centered around a gray sphere, symbolizing the human eye, and the background is plain white, emphasizing the wheel's colors. The video concludes with a static image of the color wheel, highlighting the relationship between colors and their corresponding wavelengths.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing how the color of a solution is determined by transmitted wavelengths, rather than absorbed ones, in an explanatory tone. He then mentions the color wheel in connection to art classes.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a color wheel featuring a gradient of colors arranged in a circular pattern, with numbers from 1 to 36 marking each segment. The text "complementary colors" appears in pink at the top of the wheel, indicating the focus on color theory. A yellow circle highlights the number 1, and a red circle highlights the number 19, demonstrating the concept of complementary colors. The scene transitions to a gray background with a simple black circle divided into six equal segments. The word "Red" appears in red text at the top left, followed by the addition of other colors: "Orange" in orange, "Yellow" in yellow, "Green" in green, "Blue" in blue, and "Violet" in purple, each placed in their respective segments. The acronym "ROY G BIV" is displayed at the bottom, representing the order of colors in a rainbow. The video effectively illustrates the concept of complementary colors and the sequence of colors in a rainbow using visual aids and text.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining complementary colors and how they relate to solutions absorbing certain wavelengths. The speaker adopts an informative, somewhat academic tone. Subsequently, the speaker suggests drawing a color wheel and dividing it into six sections.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a colorful diagram of a color wheel, featuring the primary colors red, blue, and yellow, along with secondary colors orange, green, and violet, arranged in a circular pattern. The acronym "ROY G BIV" is displayed below the wheel, representing the sequence of colors in the visible spectrum. The scene then transitions to a diagram illustrating the concept of absorption spectroscopy. A light bulb emits a beam of light that passes through a prism, dispersing it into a spectrum of colors. The spectrum is then directed towards a sample, which absorbs certain wavelengths, resulting in a spectrum with dark lines. The absorbed wavelengths are then detected by a detector, represented by a yellow rectangle, and the resulting pattern is displayed as a spiked graph. The video continues to show the absorption spectroscopy process, with the light bulb emitting light that passes through a prism, dispersing it into a spectrum of colors. The spectrum is then directed towards a sample, which absorbs certain wavelengths, resulting in a spectrum with dark lines. The absorbed wavelengths are then detected by a detector, represented by a yellow rectangle, and the resulting pattern is displayed as a spiked graph. The video concludes with a second light bulb emitting light that passes through a prism, dispersing it into a spectrum of colors. The spectrum is then directed towards a sample, which absorbs certain wavelengths, resulting in a spectrum with dark lines. The absorbed wavelengths are then detected by a detector, represented by a yellow rectangle, and the resulting pattern is displayed as a spiked graph. The video effectively demonstrates the process of absorption spectroscopy, highlighting the absorption of specific wavelengths by a sample and the resulting detection pattern.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing a variation on a spectrometer setup. The speaker describes a common design and then proceeds to explain an alternative arrangement, detailing how the light and monochromator are positioned in relation to the sample.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a diagram illustrating the concept of absorption spectroscopy. It features two light bulbs, each emitting a beam of light that passes through a prism, splitting the light into its constituent colors. The beams then pass through a brown rectangular object, which absorbs certain wavelengths, leaving a spectrum of colors. The remaining light continues to a yellow rectangular object, which further filters the light, resulting in a beam of red light that is directed towards a starburst pattern, symbolizing the detection of the absorbed wavelengths. The text "Absorption spectroscopy" is prominently displayed at the top of the diagram, explaining the process being depicted. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a laboratory instrument, likely a spectrophotometer, with a dial and knobs, indicating its use in measuring the intensity of light absorbed by a sample. The background is a solid purple color, providing a clear contrast to the white instrument. The video concludes with a static shot of the spectrophotometer, emphasizing its role in the absorption spectroscopy process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker discussing the benefit of a "second design," stating it allows more light to hit a sample, potentially causing a photochemical response. He notes that this design is used in a "Spec 20," an instrument likely encountered in lab courses. The speaker's tone is informative and matter-of-fact.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a white electronic device featuring a black analog meter, a black button, and two black knobs, set against a purple background. The scene transitions to a diagram illustrating energy levels, with a yellow sphere representing an electron moving between levels, accompanied by a blue curve indicating energy transitions. The next frame introduces the term "Emission Spectroscopy" in pink text, with a yellow heating coil depicted below it, and a red arrow pointing to the coil labeled "Heating Coil." The video concludes with a pink arrow pointing away from the heating coil, suggesting the emission of energy or light, while the background remains a consistent gray throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing absorption and emission interactions between molecules and photons, explaining that emission occurs when electrons in higher energy states lose energy to fall into a lower state, emitting a photon. He describes a new experimental set up to facilitate this, including a sample chamber and heating coil to excite electrons in the sample, eventually emitting light. Just as in the second absorption spectrometer, emitted light passes through a monochromator and a slit to hit the detector.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a diagram illustrating the concept of Emission Spectroscopy, featuring a heating coil, a prism, and a spectrum of colors, with a red arrow pointing to the heating coil and a pink arrow indicating the direction of light. The title "Emission Spectroscopy" is displayed in pink at the top of the frame. The scene then transitions to a dark background where a stick figure made of glowing neon lines appears, dancing with its arms and legs moving in various directions. The figure is outlined in green, with a brown head and green eyes. As the video progresses, more stick figures join in, each with different colors and poses, creating a lively and colorful dance sequence. The figures are outlined in green, blue, and yellow, with brown heads and green eyes, and they move in sync with each other. The video concludes with a text screen displaying the opening and closing music credits in green and blue text against a black background, with the opening music credited to "Jazzy Frenchy" by Benjamin Tissot and the closing music credited to "Loopster" by Kevin MacLeod.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker concluding a presentation, mentioning "new material" and previewing the next video about "phosphorescence and fluorescence." The tone is informative and friendly, and the speaker then wishes the listener a good week. Following the speech, a short, upbeat instrumental music clip plays, featuring a plucked string instrument and percussion, creating a light and playful mood.
